title: Neanderthal
text:
Neanderthals (, also Neandertals, "Homo neanderthalensis" or "Homo sapiens neanderthalensis") are an extinct <a href="species">species</a> or <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> of <a href="archaic%20humans">archaic humans</a> who lived in <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a> until about 40,000 years ago. While the cause of their extinction remains “highly contested,” demographic factors like small population size, inbreeding, and random fluctuations are considered likely factors. Other scholars have proposed competitive replacement, assimilation into the modern <a href="human%20genome">human genome</a> (bred into extinction), great <a href="climate%20change">climatic change</a>, disease, or a combination of these factors. 
It is unclear when the line of Neanderthals split from that of <a href="modern%20human">modern human</a>s; studies have produced various intervals ranging from 315,000 to more than 800,000 years ago. The time of divergence of Neanderthals from their ancestor "<a href="Homo%20heidelbergensis">H. heidelbergensis</a>" is also unclear. The oldest potential Neanderthal bones date to 430,000 years ago, but the classification remains uncertain. Neanderthals are known from numerous fossils, especially from after 130,000 years ago. The <a href="type%20specimen">type specimen</a>, <a href="Neanderthal%201">Neanderthal 1</a>, was found in 1856 in the <a href="Neander%20Valley">Neander Valley</a> in present-day Germany. For much of the early 20th Century, researchers depicted Neanderthals as primitive, unintelligent, and brutish. Although knowledge and perception of them has markedly changed since then in the scientific community, the image of the unevolved <a href="caveman">caveman</a> <a href="archetype">archetype</a> remains prevalent in popular culture.
Neanderthal technology was quite sophisticated. It includes the <a href="Mousterian">Mousterian</a> stone-tool industry and the ability to create fire and build cave <a href="hearth">hearth</a>s, make the adhesive <a href="birch%20bark%20tar">birch bark tar</a>, craft at least simple clothes similar to blankets and ponchos, weave, go seafaring through the Mediterranean, make use of <a href="medicinal%20plants%23Prehistoric%20times">medicinal plants</a>, as well as treat severe injuries, store food, and use various cooking techniques such as <a href="roasting">roasting</a>, boiling, and <a href="smoking%20%28cooking%29">smoking</a>. Neanderthals made use of a wide array of food, mainly <a href="ungulate">hoofed mammal</a>s, but also other <a href="Pleistocene%20megafauna">megafauna</a>, plants, small mammals, birds, and aquatic and marine resources. Although they were probably <a href="apex%20predator">apex predator</a>s, they still competed with <a href="cave%20bear">cave bear</a>s, <a href="Panthera%20spelaea">cave lions</a>, <a href="cave%20hyaena">cave hyaena</a>s, and other large predators. A number of examples of symbolic thought and <a href="Art%20of%20the%20Middle%20Paleolithic">Palaeolithic art</a> have been inconclusively attributed to Neanderthals, namely possible ornaments made from bird bones or shells, collections of unusual objects including crystals and fossils, engravings, music production indicated by the <a href="Divje%20Babe%20Flute">Divje Babe Flute</a>, and Spanish cave-paintings contentiously dated to before 65,000 years ago. Some claims of religious beliefs have been made. Neanderthals were likely capable of speech, possibly articulate, although the complexity of their language is not known.
Compared with modern humans, Neanderthals had a more <a href="robustness%20%28morphology%29">robust</a> build and proportionally shorter limbs. Researchers often explain these features as adaptations to conserve heat in a cold climate, but they may also have been adaptations for sprinting in the warmer, forested landscape that Neanderthals often inhabited. Nonetheless, they had cold-specific adaptations, such as specialised body-fat storage and an enlarged nose to warm air (although the nose could have been caused by <a href="genetic%20drift">genetic drift</a>). Average Neanderthal men stood around and women tall, similar to pre-industrial modern humans. The braincases of Neanderthal men and women averaged about and respectively, which is within the range of the values for modern humans. The Neanderthal skull was more elongated and had smaller parietal lobes and cerebellum, morphological traits used to assign specimens to species.
The total population of Neanderthals remained low, proliferating weakly harmful gene variants, and precluding effective long-distance networks. Nonetheless, there is evidence of regional cultures and thus of regular communication between communities. They may have frequented caves, and moved between caves seasonally. Neanderthals lived in a <a href="Stress%20%28biology%29">high-stress</a> environment with high trauma rates, and about 80% died before the age of 40. The 2010 <a href="Neanderthal%20genome%20project">Neanderthal genome project</a>'s draft report presented evidence for <a href="Interbreeding%20between%20archaic%20and%20modern%20humans">interbreeding between Neanderthals and modern humans</a>. It possibly occurred 316–219 ,000 years ago, but more likely 100,000 years ago and again 65,000 years ago. Neanderthals also appear to have interbred with <a href="Denisovans">Denisovans</a>, a different group of archaic humans, in Siberia. Around 1–4% of genomes of <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>ns, <a href="Australo-Melanesians">Australo-Melanesians</a>, <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Native Americans</a>, and <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>ns is of Neanderthal ancestry, while the inhabitants of <a href="sub-Saharan%20Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a> have no detectable Neanderthal ancestry, save possible traces from early Sapiens-to-Neanderthal gene flow and/or more recent back-migration of Eurasians to Africa. In all, about 20% of distinctly Neanderthal gene variants survive today. Although many of the gene variants inherited from Neanderthals may have been detrimental and selected out, Neanderthal <a href="introgression">introgression</a> appears to have affected the modern human <a href="immune%20system">immune system</a>,
and is also implicated in several other biological functions and structures, but a large portion appears to be <a href="non-coding%20DNA">non-coding DNA</a>.
Taxonomy.
Etymology.
Neanderthals are named after the valley, the <a href="Neandertal%20%28valley%29">Neandertal</a>, in which the first identified specimen was found. The valley was spelled "Neanderthal" and the species was spelled "Neanderthaler" in German until the <a href="German%20Orthographic%20Conference%20of%201901">spelling reform of 1901</a>. The spelling "Neandertal" for the species is occasionally seen in English, even in scientific publications, but the scientific name, "H. neanderthalensis", is always spelled with "th" according to the <a href="principle%20of%20priority">principle of priority</a>. The vernacular name of the species in German is always "Neandertaler" ("inhabitant of the Neander Valley"), whereas "Neandertal" always refers to the valley. The valley itself was named after the late 17th century German theologian and hymn writer <a href="Joachim%20Neander">Joachim Neander</a>, who often visited the area. "Neanderthal" can be pronounced using the (as in ) or the standard <a href="Pronunciation%20of%20English%20%E2%9F%A8th%E2%9F%A9">English pronunciation of "th"</a> with the fricative /<a href="voiceless%20dental%20fricative">θ</a>/ (as ).
<a href="Neanderthal%201">Neanderthal 1</a>, the <a href="type%20specimen">type specimen</a>, was known as the "Neanderthal cranium" or "Neanderthal skull" in anthropological literature, and the individual reconstructed on the basis of the skull was occasionally called "the Neanderthal man". The binomial name "Homo neanderthalensis"—extending the name "Neanderthal man" from the individual specimen to the entire species, and formally recognising it as distinct from humans—was first proposed by Irish geologist <a href="William%20King%20%28geologist%29">William King</a> in a paper read to the 33rd <a href="British%20Science%20Association">British Science Association</a> in 1863. However, in 1864, he recommended that Neanderthals and modern humans be classified in different genera as he compared the Neanderthal braincase to that of a chimpanzee and argued that they were "incapable of moral and [<a href="theism">theistic</a>] conceptions".
Research history.
The first Neanderthal remains—<a href="Engis%202">Engis 2</a> (a skull)—were discovered in 1829 by Dutch naturalist <a href="Philippe-Charles%20Schmerling">Philippe-Charles Schmerling</a> in the <a href="Schmerling%20Caves">Grottes d'Engis</a>, Belgium, but he thought it was a fossil modern human skull. In 1848, <a href="Gibraltar%201">Gibraltar 1</a> from <a href="Forbes%27%20Quarry">Forbes' Quarry</a> was presented to the Gibraltar Scientific Society by their Secretary Lieutenant Edmund Henry Réné Flint, but was also thought to be a modern human skull. In 1856, local schoolteacher <a href="Johann%20Carl%20Fuhlrott">Johann Carl Fuhlrott</a> recognised bones from <a href="Kleine%20Feldhofer%20Grotte">Kleine Feldhofer Grotte</a> in Neander Valley—Neanderthal 1 (the <a href="holotype%20specimen">holotype specimen</a>)—as distinct from modern humans, and gave them to German anthropologist <a href="Hermann%20Schaaffhausen">Hermann Schaaffhausen</a> to study in 1857. It comprised the cranium, thigh bones, right arm, left <a href="humerus">humerus</a> and <a href="ulna">ulna</a>, left <a href="ilium%20%28bone%29">ilium</a> (hip bone), part of the right <a href="shoulder%20blade">shoulder blade</a>, and pieces of the <a href="rib">rib</a>s. Following <a href="Charles%20Darwin">Charles Darwin</a>'s "<a href="On%20the%20Origin%20of%20Species">On the Origin of Species</a>", Fuhlrott and Schaaffhausen argued the bones represented an ancient modern human form; Schaaffhausen, a <a href="social%20Darwinist">social Darwinist</a>, believed that humans linearly progressed from savage to civilised, and so concluded that Neanderthals were barbarous cave-dwellers. Fuhlrott and Schaaffhausen met opposition namely from the prolific pathologist <a href="Rudolf%20Virchow">Rudolf Virchow</a> who argued against defining new species based on only a single find. In 1872, Virchow erroneously interpreted Neanderthal characteristics as evidence of <a href="senility">senility</a>, disease, and malformation instead of archaicness, which stalled Neanderthal research until the end of the century.
By the early 20th century, numerous other Neanderthal discoveries were made, establishing "H. neanderthalensis" as a legitimate species. The most influential specimen was <a href="La%20Chapelle-aux-Saints%201">La Chapelle-aux-Saints 1</a> ("The Old Man") from <a href="La%20Chapelle-aux-Saints">La Chapelle-aux-Saints</a>, France. French palaeontologist <a href="Marcellin%20Boule">Marcellin Boule</a> authored several publications, among the first to establish palaeontology as a science, detailing the specimen, but reconstructed him as slouching, ape-like, and only remotely related to modern humans. The 1912 'discovery' of <a href="Piltdown%20Man">Piltdown Man</a> (a hoax), appearing much more similar to modern humans than Neanderthals, was used as evidence that multiple different and unrelated branches of primitive humans existed, and supported Boule's reconstruction of "H. neanderthalensis" as a far distant relative and an <a href="evolutionary%20dead-end">evolutionary dead-end</a>. He fuelled the popular image of Neanderthals as barbarous, slouching, club-wielding primitives; this image was reproduced for several decades and popularised in <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> works, such as the 1911 "<a href="The%20Quest%20for%20Fire">The Quest for Fire</a>" by <a href="J.-H.%20Rosny%20a%C3%AEn%C3%A9">J.-H. Rosny aîné</a> and the 1927 "" by <a href="H.%20G.%20Wells">H. G. Wells</a> where they are depicted as monsters. In 1911, Scottish anthropologist <a href="Arthur%20Keith">Arthur Keith</a> reconstructed La Chapelle-aux-Saints 1 as an immediate precursor to modern humans, sitting next to a fire, producing tools, wearing a necklace, and having a more humanlike posture, but this failed to garner much scientific rapport, and Keith later abandoned his thesis in 1915.
By the middle of the century, based on the exposure of Piltdown Man as a hoax as well as a reexamination of La Chapelle-aux-Saints 1 (who had <a href="osteoarthritis">osteoarthritis</a> which caused slouching in life) and new discoveries, the scientific community began to rework its understanding of Neanderthals. Ideas such as Neanderthal behaviour, intelligence, and culture were being discussed, and a more humanlike image of them emerged. In 1939, American anthropologist <a href="Carleton%20Coon">Carleton Coon</a> reconstructed a Neanderthal in a modern business suit and hat to emphasise that they would be, more or less, indistinguishable from modern humans had they survived into the present. <a href="William%20Golding">William Golding</a>'s 1955 novel "<a href="The%20Inheritors%20%28Golding%20novel%29">The Inheritors</a>" depicts Neanderthals as much more emotional and civilised. However, Boule's image continued to influence works until the 1960s. In modern-day, Neanderthal reconstructions are often very humanlike.
Hybridisation between Neanderthals and early modern humans had been suggested early on, such as by English anthropologist <a href="Thomas%20Huxley">Thomas Huxley</a> in 1890, Danish ethnographer <a href="Hans%20Peder%20Steensby">Hans Peder Steensby</a> in 1907, and Coon in 1962. In the early 2000s, supposed hybrid specimens were discovered: <a href="Lagar%20Velho%201">Lagar Velho 1</a> and <a href="Pe%C8%99tera%20Muierilor">Muierii 1</a>. However, similar anatomy could also have been caused by adapting to a similar environment rather than interbreeding. <a href="Neanderthal%20admixture">Neanderthal admixture</a> was found to be present in modern populations in 2010 with the mapping of the first Neanderthal genome sequence. This was based on 3 specimens in <a href="Vindija%20Cave">Vindija Cave</a>, Croatia, which contained almost 4% archaic DNA (allowing for near complete sequencing of the genome). However, there was approximately 1 error for every 200 letters (<a href="base%20pair">base pair</a>s) based on the implausibly high mutation rate, probably due to the preservation of the sample. In 2012, British-American geneticist <a href="Graham%20Coop">Graham Coop</a> hypothesised that they instead found evidence of a different archaic human species interbreeding with modern humans, which was disproven in 2013 by the sequencing of a high-quality Neanderthal genome preserved in a toe bone from Denisova Cave, Siberia.
Classification.
Neanderthals are <a href="hominid">hominid</a>s in the <a href="genus">genus</a> "<a href="Homo">Homo</a>", humans, and generally classified as a distinct <a href="species">species</a>, "H. neanderthalensis", although sometimes as a <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> of modern human as "H. sapiens neanderthalensis". This would necessitate the classification of modern humans as "<a href="Homo%20sapiens%20sapiens">H. s. sapiens</a>".
A large part of the controversy stems from the vagueness of the term "species", as it is generally used to distinguish two genetically isolated populations, but admixture between modern humans and Neanderthals is known to have occurred. However, the absence of Neanderthal-derived patrilineal <a href="Y-chromosome">Y-chromosome</a> and matrilineal <a href="mitochondrial%20DNA">mitochondrial DNA</a> (mtDNA) in modern humans, along with the underrepresentation of Neanderthal <a href="X%20chromosome">X chromosome</a> DNA, could imply reduced fertility or frequent sterility of some hybrid crosses, representing a partial biological reproductive barrier between the groups, and therefore species distinction.
In 2014, geneticist <a href="Svante%20P%C3%A4%C3%A4bo">Svante Pääbo</a> described such "<a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomic</a> wars" as unresolvable, "since there is no definition of species perfectly describing the case".
Neanderthals are thought to have been more closely related to <a href="Denisovan">Denisovan</a>s than to modern humans. Likewise, Neanderthals and Denisovans share a more recent <a href="most%20recent%20common%20ancestor">last common ancestor</a> (LCA) than to modern humans, based on <a href="nuclear%20DNA">nuclear DNA</a> (nDNA). However, Neanderthals and modern humans share a more recent mitochondrial LCA (observable by studying mtDNA). This likely resulted from an interbreeding event subsequent to the Neanderthal/Denisovan split which introduced another mtDNA line. This involved either introgression coming from an unknown archaic human into Denisovans, or introgression from an earlier unidentified modern human wave from Africa into Neanderthals.
Evolution.
It is largely thought that "<a href="Homo%20heidelbergensis">H. heidelbergensis</a>" was the last common ancestor of Neanderthals, Denisovans, and modern humans before populations became isolated in Europe, Asia, and Africa, respectively. The taxonomic distinction between "H. heidelbergensis" and Neanderthals is mostly based on a fossil gap in Europe between 300 and 243 thousand years ago during <a href="marine%20isotope%20stage">marine isotope stage</a> 8. "Neanderthals", by convention, are fossils which date to after this gap. However, 430 thousand year (<a href="kiloannum">ka</a>) old bones at <a href="Sima%20de%20los%20Huesos">Sima de los Huesos</a> could represent early Neanderthals or a closely related group, and the 400,000 year old <a href="Aroeira%203">Aroeira 3</a> could represent a transitional phase. <a href="Basal%20%28phylogenetics%29">Ancestral</a> and <a href="synapomorphy%20and%20apomorphy">derived</a> morphs could have lived concurrently. It is also possible that there was gene flow between Western Europe and Africa during the Middle Pleistocene, obscuring Neanderthal characteristics in such specimens, namely <a href="Ceprano%20Man">from Ceprano</a>, Italy, and <a href="Si%C4%87evo%20Gorge">Sićevo Gorge</a>, Serbia. The fossil record is much more complete from 130,000 years ago onwards, and specimens from this period make up the bulk of known Neanderthal skeletons. Dental remains from the Italian <a href="Visogliano">Visogliano</a> and <a href="Fontana%20Ranuccio">Fontana Ranuccio</a> sites indicate that Neanderthal dental features had evolved by around 450–430 thousand years ago during the <a href="Middle%20Pleistocene">Middle Pleistocene</a>.
There are two main hypotheses regarding the evolution of Neanderthals following the Neanderthal/human split: two-phase and accretion. Two-phase argues a single major environmental event—such as the <a href="Saale%20glaciation">Saale glaciation</a>—caused European "H. heidelbergensis" to rapidly increase body size and robustness, as well as undergo a lengthening of the head (phase 1), which then led to other changes in skull anatomy (phase 2). However, Neanderthal anatomy may not have been driven entirely by adapting to cold weather. Accretion holds that Neanderthals slowly evolved over time from the ancestral "H. heidelbergensis", divided into 4 stages: early-pre-Neanderthals (<a href="Anglian%20stage">MIS 12</a>, <a href="Elster%20glaciation">Elster glaciation</a>), pre-Neanderthals "<a href="sensu%20lato">sensu lato</a>" (MIS <a href="Marine%20Isotope%20Stage%2011">11</a>–<a href="Marine%20Isotope%20Stage%209">9</a>, <a href="Holstein%20interglacial">Holstein interglacial</a>), early Neanderthals (MIS 7–<a href="Marine%20Isotope%20Stage%205">5</a>, <a href="Saale%20glaciation">Saale glaciation</a>–<a href="Eemian">Eemian</a>), and classic Neanderthals "<a href="sensu%20stricto">sensu stricto</a>" (MIS 4–3, <a href="W%C3%BCrm%20glaciation">Würm glaciation</a>).
Numerous dates for the Neanderthal/human split have been suggested. The date of around 250,000 years ago cites ""<a href="Florisbad%20Skull">H. helmei</a>"" as being the last common ancestor (LCA), and the split is associated with the <a href="Levallois%20technique">Levallois technique</a> of making stone tools. The date of about 400,000 years ago uses "H. heidelbergensis" as the LCA. 600,000 years ago says that ""<a href="Homo%20rhodesiensis">H. rhodesiensis</a>"" was the LCA, which split off into modern human lineage and a Neanderthal/"H. heidelbergensis" lineage. 800,000 years ago has "<a href="Homo%20antecessor">H. antecessor</a>" as the LCA, but different variations of this model would push the date back to 1 million years ago. However, a 2020 analysis of "H. antecessor" enamel <a href="proteome">proteome</a>s suggests that "H. antecessor" is related but not a direct ancestor. DNA studies have yielded various results on Neanderthal/human divergence time, such as 538–315, 553–321, 565–503, 654–475, 690–550, 765–550, 741–317, and 800–520 thousand years ago; and a dental analysis concluded before 800,000 years ago.
Neanderthals and Denisovans are more closely related to each other than they are to modern humans, meaning the Neanderthal/Denisovan split occurred after their split with modern humans. Assuming a mutation rate of 1x10−9 or 0.5x10−9 per <a href="base%20pair">base pair</a> (bp) per year, the Neanderthal/Denisovan split occurred around either 236–190 or 473–381 thousand years ago respectively. Using 1.1x10−8 per generation with a new generation every 29 years, the time is 744,000 years ago. Using 5x10−10 <a href="nucleotide">nucleotide</a> sites per year, it is 644,000 years ago. Using the latter dates, the split had likely already occurred by the time hominins spread out across Europe, and unique Neanderthal features had begun evolving by 600–500 thousand years ago. Before splitting, Neanderthal/Denisovans (or "Neandersovans") migrating out of Africa into Europe apparently interbred with an unidentified "superarchaic" human species who were already present there; these superarchaics were the descendants of a very early migration out of Africa around 1.9 mya.
Demographics.
Range.
Pre- and early Neanderthals, living before the Eemian interglacial (130,000 years ago), are poorly known and come mostly from Western European sites. From 130,000 years ago onwards, the quality of the fossil record increases dramatically with classic Neanderthals, who are recorded from Western, Central, Eastern, and Mediterranean Europe, as well as <a href="Neanderthals%20in%20Southwest%20Asia">Southwest</a>, Central, and Northern Asia up to the <a href="Altai%20Mountains">Altai Mountains</a> in southern Siberia. Pre- and early Neanderthals, on the other hand, seem to have continuously occupied only France, Spain, and Italy, although some appear to have moved out of this "core-area" to form temporary settlements eastward (although without leaving Europe). Nonetheless, southwestern France has the highest density of sites for pre-, early, and classic Neanderthals.
The southernmost find was recorded at <a href="Shuqba%20Cave">Shuqba Cave</a>, Levant; reports of Neanderthals from the North African <a href="Jebel%20Irhoud">Jebel Irhoud</a> and <a href="Haua%20Fteah">Haua Fteah</a> have been reidentified as "H. sapiens". Their easternmost presence is recorded at <a href="Denisova%20Cave">Denisova Cave</a>, Siberia <a href="85th%20meridian%20east">85°E</a>; the southeast Chinese <a href="Maba%20Man">Maba Man</a>, a skull, shares several physical attributes with Neanderthals, although these may be the result of <a href="convergent%20evolution">convergent evolution</a> rather than Neanderthals extending their range to the Pacific Ocean. The northernmost bound is generally accepted to have been <a href="55th%20parallel%20north">55°N</a>, with unambiguous sites known between <a href="50th%20parallel%20north">50</a>–<a href="53rd%20parallel%20north">53°N</a>, although this is difficult to assess because glacial advances destroy most human remains, and palaeoanthropologist Trine Kellberg Nielsen has argued that a lack of evidence of Southern Scandinavian occupation is (at least during the Eemian interglacial) due to the former explanation and a lack of research in the area. Middle Palaeolithic artefacts have been found up to 60°N on the Russian plains, but these are more likely attributed to modern humans. A 2017 study claimed the presence of "Homo" at the 130,000 year old Californian <a href="Cerutti%20Mastodon%20site">Cerutti Mastodon site</a> in North America, but this is largely considered implausible.
It is unknown how the rapidly fluctuating climate of the <a href="last%20glacial%20period">last glacial period</a> (<a href="Dansgaard%E2%80%93Oeschger%20event">Dansgaard–Oeschger event</a>s) impacted Neanderthals, as warming periods would produce more favourable temperatures but encourage forest growth and deter megafauna, whereas frigid periods would produce the opposite. However, Neanderthals may have preferred a forested landscape. Populations may have peaked in cold but not extreme intervals, such as marine isotope stages 8 and 6 (respectively 300 and 191 thousand years ago during the Saale glaciation). It is possible their range expanded and contracted as the ice retreated and grew respectively to avoid <a href="permafrost">permafrost</a> areas, residing in certain <a href="Refugium%20%28population%20biology%29">refuge zones</a> during glacial maxima. In 2021, Israeli anthropologist Israel Hershkovitz and colleagues suggested the 140 to 120 thousand years old Israeli <a href="Nesher%20Ramla%20Homo">Nesher Ramla</a> remains, which feature a mix of Neanderthal and more ancient "<a href="Homo%20erectus">H. erectus</a>" traits, represent one such source population which recolonised Europe following a glacial period.
Population.
Like modern humans, Neanderthals probably descended from a very small population with an <a href="effective%20population">effective population</a>—the number of individuals who can bear or father children—of 3,000 to 12,000 approximately. However, Neanderthals maintained this very low population, proliferating weakly harmful genes due to the reduced effectivity of <a href="natural%20selection">natural selection</a>.
Various studies, using <a href="mtDNA">mtDNA</a> analysis, yield varying effective populations, such as about 1,000 to 5,000; 5,000 to 9,000 remaining constant; or 3,000 to 25,000 steadily increasing until 52,000 years ago before declining until extinction. However, all agree on low population, which may have been less than 1/10th of the contemporary human populations in Western Europe possibly because Neanderthals had much lower fertility rates. Estimates giving a total population in the higher tens of thousands are contested. A consistently low population may be explained in the context of the "<a href="Ester%20Boserup">Boserupian Trap</a>": a population's <a href="carrying%20capacity">carrying capacity</a> is limited by the amount of food it can obtain, which in turn is limited by its technology. Innovation increases with population, but if the population is too low, innovation will not occur very rapidly and the population will remain low. This is consistent with the apparent 150,000 year stagnation in Neanderthal lithic technology.
In a sample of 206 Neanderthals, based on the abundance of young and mature adults in comparison to other age demographics, about 80% of them above the age of 20 died before reaching 40. This high mortality rate was probably due to their high-stress environment. However, it has also been estimated that the <a href="age%20pyramid">age pyramid</a>s for Neanderthals and contemporary modern humans were the same. Infant mortality was estimated to have been very high for Neanderthals, about 43% in northern Eurasia.
Anatomy.
Build.
Neanderthals had more <a href="robustness%20%28morphology%29">robust</a> and stockier builds than modern humans, wider and barrel-shaped rib cages; wider pelvises; and proportionally shorter forearms and forelegs.
Based on 45 Neanderthal <a href="long%20bone">long bone</a>s from 14 men and 7 women, the average height was for males and for females. For comparison, the average height of 28 males and 10 females Upper Palaeolithic humans is respectively and , although this decreases by nearer the end of the period based on 21 males and 15 females; and the average in the year 1900 was and , respectively. The fossil record shows adult Neanderthals varied from about in height, although some may have grown much taller. For Neanderthal weight, samples of 26 specimens found an average of for males and for females. Using , the <a href="body%20mass%20index">body mass index</a> for Neanderthal males was calculated to be 26.9–28.2, which in modern humans correlates to being <a href="overweight">overweight</a>. This indicates a very robust build. The Neanderthal <a href="LEPR">LEPR</a> gene concerned with storing fat and <a href="thermogenesis">body heat production</a> is similar to that of the <a href="woolly%20mammoth">woolly mammoth</a>, and so was likely an adaptation for cold climate.
The <a href="neck%20vertebra">neck vertebra</a>e of Neanderthals are longer and thicker than those of modern humans, lending to stability, possibly due to different head shape and size. Although the Neanderthal <a href="thorax">thorax</a> (where the <a href="ribcage">ribcage</a> is) was similar in size to modern humans, the longer and straighter ribs would have equated to a widened mid-lower thorax and stronger breathing in the lower thorax, which are indicative of a larger <a href="Thoracic%20diaphragm">diaphragm</a> and possibly greater <a href="lung%20capacity">lung capacity</a>. The lung capacity of <a href="Kebara%202">Kebara 2</a> was estimated to have been . The Neanderthal chest was also more pronounced (expanded front-to-back, or antero-posteriorly). The <a href="sacrum">sacrum</a> (where the <a href="pelvis">pelvis</a> connects to the <a href="vertebral%20column">spine</a>) was more vertically inclined, and was placed lower in relation to the pelvis, causing the spine to be less curved (exhibit less <a href="lordosis">lordosis</a>) and to fold in on itself somewhat (to be invaginated). Such modifications to the spine would have enhanced side-to-side (mediolateral) <a href="flexion">flexion</a>, better supporting the wider lower thorax. This condition may be normal for "Homo", with the condition of a narrower thorax in modern humans being a unique characteristic.
Body proportions are usually cited as being "hyperarctic" as adaptations to the cold, because they are similar to those of human populations which developed in cold climates—the Neanderthal build is most similar to that of <a href="Inuit">Inuit</a> and <a href="Siberian%20Yupik">Siberian Yupik</a>s among modern humans—and shorter limbs equates to higher retention of body heat. Nonetheless, Neanderthals from more temperate climates—such as Iberia—still retain the "hyperarctic" physique. In 2019, English anthropologist John Stewart and colleagues suggested Neanderthals instead were adapted for sprinting because of evidence of Neanderthals preferring more warmer wooded areas over the colder <a href="mammoth%20steppe">mammoth steppe</a>, and DNA analysis indicating a higher proportion of <a href="skeletal%20muscle%23Physics">fast-twitch muscle fibres</a> in Neanderthals than modern humans. He explained their body proportions and greater muscle mass as adaptations to sprinting as opposed to the <a href="endurance%20running%20hypothesis">endurance-oriented modern human physique</a>, as <a href="persistence%20hunting">persistence hunting</a> may only be effective in hot climates where the hunter can run prey to the point of heat exhaustion (<a href="hyperthermia">hyperthermia</a>). They had longer <a href="heel%20bone">heel bone</a>s, reducing their ability for endurance running, and their shorter limbs would have reduced <a href="moment%20arm">moment arm</a> at the limbs, allowing for greater <a href="rotational%20force">rotational force</a> at the wrists and ankles without extra exertion of the rotating muscles at the elbows and knees by increasing the speed at which the muscles contracted, causing faster acceleration. In 1981, American palaeoanthropologist <a href="Erik%20Trinkaus">Erik Trinkaus</a> made note of this alternate explanation, but considered it less likely.
Face.
Neanderthals had a reduced chin, sloping forehead, and large nose, which also started somewhat higher on the face than in modern humans. The Neanderthal skull is typically more elongated and less globular than that of modern humans, and features an <a href="occipital%20bun">occipital bun</a>, or "chignon", a protrusion on the back of the skull, although it is within the range of variation for humans who have it. It is caused by the <a href="cranial%20base">cranial base</a> and <a href="temporal%20bone">temporal bone</a>s being placed higher and more towards the front of the skull, and a flatter <a href="calvaria%20%28skull%29">skullcap</a>. They also had larger eyes likely to adapt to the low-light environment.
The large Neanderthal nose and <a href="paranasal%20sinus">paranasal sinus</a>es have generally been explained as having warmed air as it entered the lungs and retained moisture ("nasal radiator" hypothesis); but sinuses are generally reduced in cold-adapted creatures, and it may have been that the large nose was caused instead by <a href="genetic%20drift">genetic drift</a>. Also, the sinuses are not grossly large, and are comparable in size to those of modern humans. However, sinus size is not an important factor for breathing cold air, and their actual function is unclear, so they may not be a good indicator of evolutionary pressures to evolve such a nose. Further, a computer reconstruction of the Neanderthal nose and predicted soft tissue patterns shows some similarities to those of modern Arctic peoples, potentially meaning the noses of both populations convergently evolved for breathing cold, dry air.
Neanderthals featured a protrusion of the jaw (<a href="prognathism">prognathism</a>), which was once cited as a response to a large <a href="bite%20force">bite force</a> evidenced by heavy wearing of Neanderthal front teeth (the "anterior dental loading" hypothesis), but similar wearing trends are seen in contemporary humans. It could also have evolved to fit larger teeth in the jaw, which would better resist wear and abrasion, and the increased wear on the front teeth compared to the back teeth probably stems from repetitive use. Neanderthal dental wear patterns are most similar to those of modern Inuit. The incisors are large and shovel-shaped, and, compared to modern humans, there was an unusually high frequency of <a href="taurodontism">taurodontism</a>, a condition where the <a href="molar%20tooth">molars</a> are bulkier due to an enlarged <a href="pulp%20%28tooth%29">pulp</a> (tooth core). Taurodontism was once thought to have been a distinguishing characteristic of Neanderthals which lent some mechanical advantage or stemmed from repetitive use, but was more likely simply a product of genetic drift. The bite force of Neanderthals and modern humans is now thought to be about the same, about and in modern human males and females, respectively.
Brain.
The Neanderthal braincase averages for males and for females, within the possible range of modern humans, which is, on average, for males and for females in present-day. For 28 modern human specimens from 190 to 25 thousand years ago, the average was about disregarding sex, and modern human brain size is suggested to have decreased since the Upper Palaeolithic. The largest Neanderthal brain, <a href="Amud%201">Amud 1</a>, was calculated to be , one of the largest ever recorded in hominids. Both Neanderthal and human infants measure about .
The Neanderthal skull is distinctively elongated, a diagnostic shape known as en bombe, with smaller parietal lobes and a smaller <a href="cerebellum">cerebellum</a>, areas implicated in tool use, visuospatial integration, numeracy, creativity, higher-order conceptualization, <a href="muscle%20memory">muscle memory</a>, and possibly language, attention, <a href="working%20memory">working memory</a>, social abilities, and <a href="episodic%20memory">episodic memory</a>. Neanderthal brains also have larger <a href="occipital%20lobe">occipital lobes</a>, likely an adaptation to lower light conditions in Europe that implies internal differences in the proportionality of brain-internal regions, relative to "Homo sapiens," consistent with external measurements obtained with fossil skulls. Their brains also have larger temporal lobe poles, wider orbitofrontal cortex, and larger olfactory bulbs, suggesting potential differences in language comprehension and associations with emotions (<a href="temporal%20lobe">temporal functions</a>), decision making (the <a href="orbitofrontal%20cortex">orbitofrontal cortex</a>), and sense of smell (<a href="olfactory%20bulbs">olfactory bulbs</a>). Their brains also show different rates of brain growth and development. Such differences, while slight, would have been visible to natural selection and may underlie and explain differences in the material record in things like social behaviors, technological innovation, and artistic output.
Hair and skin colour.
The lack of sunlight most likely led to the proliferation of lighter skin in Neanderthals, although light skin in modern Europeans was not particularly prolific until perhaps the <a href="Bronze%20Age">Bronze Age</a>. Genetically, <a href="BNC2">BNC2</a> was present in Neanderthals, which is associated with light skin colour; however, a second variation of BNC2 was also present, which is associated with darker skin colour in the <a href="UK%20Biobank">UK Biobank</a>. It is likely Neanderthal skin colour varied from region to region. The DNA of three Croatian Neanderthals shows they had darker hair, skin, and eye colour than modern Europeans.
In modern humans, skin and hair colour is regulated by the <a href="melanocyte-stimulating%20hormone">melanocyte-stimulating hormone</a>—which increases the proportion of <a href="eumelanin">eumelanin</a> (black pigment) to <a href="phaeomelanin">phaeomelanin</a> (red pigment)—which is encoded by the MC1R gene. There are 5 known variants in modern humans of the gene which cause loss-of-function and are associated with light skin and hair colour, and another unknown variant in Neanderthals (the R307G variant) which could be associated with pale skin and red hair. The R307G variant was identified in a Neanderthal from <a href="Valpolicella">Monti Lessini</a>, Italy, and possibly Cueva del Sidrón, Spain. However, as in modern humans, red was probably not a very common hair colour because the variant is not present in many other sequenced Neanderthals.
Metabolism.
Maximum natural lifespan and the timing of adulthood, <a href="menopause">menopause</a>, and <a href="gestation">gestation</a> were most likely very similar to modern humans. However, it has been hypothesised that Neanderthals matured faster than modern humans based on the growth rates of teeth and <a href="tooth%20enamel">tooth enamel</a>, although this is not backed up by age <a href="biomarker">biomarker</a>s. The main differences in maturation are the <a href="atlas%20%28anatomy%29">atlas bone</a> in the neck as well as the middle thoracic vertebrae fused about 2 years later in Neanderthals than in modern humans, but this was more likely caused by a difference in anatomy rather than growth rate.
Generally, models on Neanderthal <a href="calorie">caloric requirements</a> report significantly higher intakes than those of modern humans because they typically assume Neanderthals had higher <a href="basal%20metabolic%20rate">basal metabolic rate</a>s (BMRs) due to higher muscle mass, faster growth rate, and greater body heat production against the cold; and higher daily <a href="physical%20activity%20level">physical activity level</a>s (PALs) due to greater daily travelling distances while foraging. However, using a high BMR and PAL, American archaeologist Bryan Hockett estimated that a pregnant Neanderthal would have consumed 5,500 calories per day, which would have necessitated a heavy reliance on big game meat; such a diet would have caused numerous deficiencies or nutrient poisonings, so he concluded that these are poorly warranted assumptions to make.
Neanderthals may have been more active during dimmer light conditions rather than broad daylight because they lived in regions with reduced daytime hours, hunted large game (such predators typically hunt at night to enhance ambush tactics), and had large eyes and visual processing neural centres. Genetically, <a href="colour%20blindness">colour blindness</a> (which may enhance <a href="mesopic%20vision">mesopic vision</a>) is typically correlated with northern-latitude populations, and the Neanderthals from Vindija Cave, Croatia, had some substitutions in the <a href="Opsin">Opsin</a> genes which could have influenced colour vision. However, the functional implications of these substitutions are inconclusive. Neanderthal-derived alleles near <a href="ASB1">ASB1</a> and <a href="EXOC6">EXOC6</a> are associated with being an <a href="evening%20person">evening person</a>, <a href="narcolepsy">narcolepsy</a>, and day-time napping.
Pathology.
Neanderthals suffered a high rate of traumatic injury, with an estimated 79–94% of specimens showing evidence of healed major trauma, of which 37–52% were severely injured, and 13–19% injured before reaching adulthood. One extreme example is <a href="Shanidar%201">Shanidar 1</a>, who shows signs of an <a href="amputation">amputation</a> of the right arm likely due to a <a href="nonunion">nonunion</a> after breaking a bone in adolescence, <a href="osteomyelitis">osteomyelitis</a> (a bone infection) on the left <a href="clavicle">clavicle</a>, an abnormal <a href="gait">gait</a>, vision problems in the left eye, and possible hearing loss (perhaps <a href="swimmer%27s%20ear">swimmer's ear</a>). In 1995, Trinkaus estimated that about 80% succumbed to their injuries and died before reaching 40, and thus theorised that Neanderthals employed a risky hunting strategy ("rodeo rider" hypothesis). However, rates of cranial trauma are not significantly different between Neanderthals and Middle Palaeolithic modern humans (although Neanderthals seem to have had a higher mortality risk), there are few specimens of both Upper Palaeolithic modern humans and Neanderthals who died after the age of 40, and there are overall similar injury patterns between them. In 2012, Trinkaus concluded that Neanderthals instead injured themselves in the same way as contemporary humans, such as by interpersonal violence. A 2016 study looking at 124 Neanderthal specimens argued that high trauma rates were instead caused by <a href="animal%20attack">animal attack</a>s, and found that about 36% of the sample were victims of <a href="bear%20attack">bear attack</a>s, 21% big cat attacks, and 17% <a href="wolf%20attack">wolf attack</a>s (totalling 92 positive cases, 74%). There were no cases of hyaena attacks, although hyaenas still nonetheless probably attacked Neanderthals, at least opportunistically. Such intense predation probably stemmed from common confrontations due to competition over food and cave space, and from Neanderthals hunting these carnivores.
Low population caused a low <a href="genetic%20diversity">genetic diversity</a> and probably inbreeding, which reduced the population's ability to filter out <a href="harmful%20mutation">harmful mutation</a>s (<a href="inbreeding%20depression">inbreeding depression</a>). However, it is unknown how this affected a single Neanderthal's genetic burden and, thus, if this caused a higher rate of <a href="birth%20defect">birth defect</a>s than in modern humans. It is known, however, that the 13 inhabitants of Sidrón Cave collectively exhibited 17 different birth defects likely due to inbreeding or <a href="genetic%20disorder">recessive disorders</a>. Likely due to advanced age (60s or 70s), La Chapelle-aux-Saints 1 had signs of <a href="Baastrup%27s%20disease">Baastrup's disease</a>, affecting the spine, and osteoarthritis. Shanidar 1, who likely died at about 30 or 40, was diagnosed with the most ancient case of <a href="diffuse%20idiopathic%20skeletal%20hyperostosis">diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis</a> (DISH), a degenerative disease which can restrict movement, which, if correct, would indicate a moderately high incident rate for older Neanderthals.
Neanderthals were likely subject to several infectious diseases and parasites. Modern humans likely transmitted diseases to them; one possible candidate is the stomach bacteria "<a href="Helicobacter%20pylori">Helicobacter pylori</a>". The modern <a href="human%20papillomavirus%20infection">human papillomavirus</a> variant 16A may descend from Neanderthal introgression. A Neanderthal at Cueva del Sidrón, Spain, shows evidence of a gastrointestinal "<a href="Enterocytozoon%20bieneusi">Enterocytozoon bieneusi</a>" infection. The leg bones of the French <a href="La%20Ferrassie%201">La Ferrassie 1</a> feature lesions that are consistent with <a href="periostitis">periostitis</a>—inflammation of the tissue enveloping the bone—likely a result of <a href="hypertrophic%20osteoarthropathy">hypertrophic osteoarthropathy</a>, which is primarily caused by a chest infection or <a href="lung%20cancer">lung cancer</a>. Neanderthals had a lower <a href="tooth%20decay">cavity</a> rate than modern humans, despite some populations consuming typically cavity-causing foods in great quantity, which could indicate a lack of cavity-causing oral bacteria, namely "<a href="Streptococcus%20mutans">Streptococcus mutans</a>".
Two 250,000-year-old Neanderthal children from <a href="Payr%C3%A9">Payré</a>, France, present the earliest known cases of <a href="lead%20exposure">lead exposure</a> of any hominin. They were exposed on two distinct occasions either by eating or drinking contaminated food or water, or inhaling lead-laced smoke from a fire. There are two lead mines within of the site.
Culture.
Social structure.
Group dynamics.
Neanderthals likely lived in more sparsely distributed groups than contemporary modern humans, but group size is thought to have averaged 10 to 30 individuals, similar to modern hunter-gatherers. Reliable evidence of Neanderthal group composition comes from Cueva del Sidrón, Spain, and the footprints at Le Rozel, France: the former shows 7 adults, 3 adolescents, 2 juveniles, and an infant; whereas the latter, based on footprint size, shows a group of 10 to 13 members where juveniles and adolescents made up 90%.
A Neanderthal child's teeth analysed in 2018 showed it was weaned after 2.5 years, similar to modern hunter gatherers, and was born in the spring, which is consistent with modern humans and other mammals whose birth cycles coincide with environmental cycles. Indicated from various ailments resulting from high stress at a low age, such as <a href="stunted%20growth">stunted growth</a>, British archaeologist <a href="Paul%20Pettitt">Paul Pettitt</a> hypothesised that children of both sexes were put to work directly after weaning; and Trinkaus said that, upon reaching adolescence, an individual may have been expected to join in hunting large and dangerous game. However, the bone trauma is comparable to modern Inuit, which could suggest a similar childhood between Neanderthals and contemporary modern humans. Further, such stunting may have also resulted from harsh winters and bouts of low food resources.
Sites showing evidence of no more than three individuals may have represented <a href="nuclear%20families">nuclear families</a> or temporary camping sites for special task groups (such as a hunting party). Bands likely moved between certain caves depending on the season, indicated by remains of seasonal materials such as certain foods, and returned to the same locations generation after generation. Some sites may have been used for over 100 years. <a href="Cave%20bear">Cave bear</a>s may have greatly competed with Neanderthals for cave space, and there is a decline in cave bear populations starting 50,000 years ago onwards (although their extinction occurred well after Neanderthals had died out). Although Neanderthals are generally considered to have been cave dwellers, with 'home base' being a cave, open-air settlements near contemporaneously inhabited cave systems in the Levant could indicate mobility between cave and open-air bases in this area. Evidence for long-term open-air settlements is known from the '<a href="Ein%20Qashish">Ein Qashish</a> site in Israel, and Moldova I in Ukraine. Although Neanderthals appear to have had the ability to inhabit a range of environments—including plains and plateaux—open-air Neanderthals sites are generally interpreted as having been used as slaughtering and butchering grounds rather than living spaces.
Inter-group relations.
Canadian <a href="ethnoarchaeology">ethnoarchaeologist</a> Brian Hayden calculated a self-sustaining population that avoids inbreeding to consist of about 450–500 individuals, which would necessitate these bands to interact with 8–53 other bands, but more likely the more conservative estimate given low population density. Analysis of the mtDNA of the Neanderthals of Cueva del Sidrón, Spain, showed that the three adult men belonged to the same maternal lineage, while the three adult women belonged to different ones. This suggests a <a href="patrilocal%20residence">patrilocal residence</a> (that a woman moved out of her group to live with her husband). However, the DNA of a Neanderthal from Denisova Cave, Russia, shows that she had an inbreeding coefficient of (her parents were either <a href="half-sibling">half-sibling</a>s with a common mother, <a href="double%20first%20cousin">double first cousin</a>s, an uncle and niece or aunt and nephew, or a grandfather and granddaughter or grandmother and grandson) and the inhabitants of Cueva del Sidrón show several defects, which may have been caused by inbreeding or recessive disorders.
Considering most Neanderthal artefacts were sourced no more than from the main settlement, Hayden considered it unlikely these bands interacted very often, and mapping of the Neanderthal brain and their small group size and population density could indicate that they had a reduced ability for inter-group interaction and trade. However, a few Neanderthal artefacts in a settlement could have originated 20, 30, 100, and 300 km (12.5, 18.5, 60, and 185 mi) away. Based on this, Hayden also speculated that macro-bands formed which functioned much like those of the low-density hunter-gatherer societies of the <a href="Western%20Desert%20cultural%20bloc">Western Desert</a> of Australia. Macro-bands collectively encompass , with each band claiming , maintaining strong alliances for mating networks or to cope with leaner times and enemies. Similarly, British anthropologist Eiluned Pearce and Cypriot archaeologist Theodora Moutsiou speculated that Neanderthals were possibly capable of forming geographically expansive <a href="ethnolinguistic%20group">ethnolinguistic tribes</a> encompassing upwards of 800 people, based on the transport of <a href="obsidian">obsidian</a> up to from the source compared to trends seen in obsidian transfer distance and tribe size in modern hunter-gatherers. However, likely due to a significantly lower population, their model also reported that Neanderthals would not have been as efficient at maintaining long-distance networks as contemporary humans. Hayden noted an apparent cemetery of six or seven individuals at <a href="La%20Ferrassie">La Ferrassie</a>, France, which, in modern humans, is typically used as evidence of a <a href="corporate%20group%20%28sociology%29">corporate group</a> which maintained a distinct social identity and controlled some resource, trading, manufacturing, and so on. La Ferrassie is also located in one of the richest animal-migration routes of Pleistocene Europe.
Genetic analysis indicates there were at least 3 distinct geographical groups—Western Europe, the Mediterranean coast, and east of the Caucasus—with some migration among these regions. Post-Eemian Western European <a href="Mousterian">Mousterian</a> <a href="lithic%20technology">lithics</a> can also be broadly grouped into 3 distinct macro-regions: Acheulean-tradition Mousterian in the southwest, <a href="Micoquien">Micoquien</a> in the northeast, and Mousterian with bifacial tools (MBT) in between the former two. MBT may actually represent the interactions and fusion of the two different cultures. Southern Neanderthals exhibit regional anatomical differences from northern counterparts: a less protrusive jaw, a shorter gap behind the molars, and a vertically higher jawbone. These all instead suggest Neanderthal communities regularly interacted with neighbouring communities within a region, but not as often beyond.
Nonetheless, over long periods of time, there is evidence of large-scale cross-continental migration. Early specimens from <a href="Mezmaiskaya%20Cave">Mezmaiskaya Cave</a> in the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and <a href="Denisova%20Cave">Denisova Cave</a> in the Siberian Altai Mountains differ genetically from those found in Western Europe, whereas later specimens from these caves both have genetic profiles more similar to Western European Neanderthal specimens than to the earlier specimens from the same locations, suggesting long-range migration and population replacement over time. Similarly, artefacts and DNA from <a href="Chagyrskaya%20Cave">Chagyrskaya</a> and <a href="Okladnikov%20Cave">Okladnikov</a> Caves, also in the Altai Mountains, resemble those of eastern European Neanderthal sites about away more than they do artefacts and DNA of the older Neanderthals from Denisova Cave, suggesting two distinct migration events into Siberia. Neanderthals seem to have suffered a major population decline during MIS 4 (71–57 thousand years ago), and the distribution of the Micoquian tradition could indicate that Central Europe and the Caucasus were repopulated by communities from a refuge zone either in eastern France or Hungary (the fringes of the Micoquian tradition) who dispersed along the rivers <a href="Prut">Prut</a> and <a href="Dniester">Dniester</a>.
There is also evidence of inter-group conflict: a skeleton from <a href="La%20Roche%20%C3%A0%20Pierrot">La Roche à Pierrot</a>, France, showing a healed fracture on top of the skull apparently caused by a deep blade wound, and another from Shanadir Cave, Iraq, found to have a rib lesion characteristic of projectile weapon injuries.
Social hierarchy.
It is sometimes suggested, since they were hunters of challenging big game and lived in small groups, there was no sexual division of labour as seen in modern hunter-gatherer societies. That is, men, women, and children all had to be involved in hunting, instead of men hunting with women and children foraging. However, with modern hunter-gatherers, the higher the meat dependency, the higher the division of labour. Further, tooth-wearing patterns in Neanderthal men and women suggest they commonly used their teeth for carrying items, but men exhibit more wearing on the upper teeth, and women the lower, suggesting some cultural differences in tasks.
It is controversially proposed that some Neanderthals wore decorative clothing or jewellery—such as a leopard skin or <a href="raptor%20%28bird%29">raptor</a> feathers—to display elevated status in the group. Hayden postulated that the small number of Neanderthal graves found was because only high-ranking members would receive an elaborate burial, as is the case for some modern hunter-gatherers. Trinkaus suggested that elderly Neanderthals were given special burial rites for lasting so long given the high mortality rates. Alternatively, many more Neanderthals may have received burials, but the graves were infiltrated and destroyed by bears. Given that 20 graves of Neanderthals aged under 4 have been found—over a third of all known graves—deceased children may have received greater care during burial than other age demographics.
Looking at Neanderthal skeletons recovered from several natural rock shelters, Trinkaus said that, although Neanderthals were recorded as bearing several trauma-related injuries, none of them had significant trauma to the legs that would debilitate movement. He suggested that <a href="self%20worth">self worth</a> in Neanderthal culture derived from contributing food to the group; a debilitating injury would remove this self-worth and result in near-immediate death, and individuals who could not keep up with the group while moving from cave to cave were left behind. However, there are examples of individuals with highly debilitating injuries being nursed for several years, and caring for the most vulnerable within the community dates even further back to "H. heidelbergensis". Especially given the high trauma rates, it is possible that such an altruistic strategy ensured their survival as a species for so long.
Food.
Hunting and gathering.
Neanderthals were once thought of as <a href="scavenger">scavenger</a>s, but are now considered to have been <a href="apex%20predator">apex predator</a>s. In 1980, it was hypothesised that two piles of mammoth skulls at <a href="La%20Cotte%20de%20St%20Brelade">La Cotte de St Brelade</a>, Jersey, at the base of a gulley were evidence of mammoth <a href="game%20drive%20system">drive hunting</a> (causing them to stampede off a ledge), but this is contested. Living in a forested environment, Neanderthals were likely <a href="ambush%20hunter">ambush hunter</a>s, getting close to and attacking their target—a prime adult—in a short burst of speed, thrusting in a spear at close quarters. Younger or wounded animals may have been hunted using traps, projectiles, or pursuit. Nonetheless, they were able to adapt to a variety of habitats. They appear to have eaten predominantly what was abundant within their immediate surroundings, with steppe-dwelling communities (generally outside of the Mediterranean) subsisting almost entirely on meat from large game, forest-dwelling communities consuming a wide array of plants and smaller animals, and waterside communities gathering aquatic resources. Contemporary humans, in contrast, seem to have used more complex food extraction strategies and generally had a more diverse diet. Nonetheless, Neanderthals still would have had to have eaten a varied enough diet to prevent <a href="nutrient%20deficiencies">nutrient deficiencies</a> and <a href="protein%20poisoning">protein poisoning</a>, especially in the winter when they presumably ate mostly lean meat. Any food with high contents of other essential nutrients not provided by lean meat would have been vital components of their diet, such as fat-rich brains, carbohydrate-rich and abundant underground <a href="storage%20organ">storage organ</a>s (including roots and tubers), or, like modern Inuit, the stomach contents of herbivorous prey items.
For meat, they appear to have fed predominantly on <a href="ungulate">hoofed mammals</a>, namely <a href="red%20deer">red deer</a> and <a href="reindeer">reindeer</a> as these two were the most abundant game, but also on other <a href="Pleistocene%20megafauna">Pleistocene megafauna</a> such as <a href="Capra%20%28genus%29">ibex</a>, <a href="wild%20boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="aurochs">aurochs</a>, mammoth, <a href="straight-tusked%20elephant">straight-tusked elephant</a>, <a href="woolly%20rhinoceros">woolly rhinoceros</a>, and so on. There is evidence of directed cave and <a href="brown%20bear">brown</a> bear hunting both in and out of <a href="hibernation">hibernation</a>, as well as butchering. Analysis of Neanderthal bone <a href="collagen">collagen</a> from Vindija Cave, Croatia, shows nearly all of their protein needs derived from animal meat. Some caves show evidence of regular rabbit and tortoise consumption. At Gibraltar sites, there are remains of 143 different bird species, many ground-dwelling such as the <a href="common%20quail">common quail</a>, <a href="corn%20crake">corn crake</a>, <a href="woodlark">woodlark</a>, and <a href="crested%20lark">crested lark</a>. Neanderthals also exploited marine resources on the Iberian, Italian, and <a href="Peloponnese">Peloponnesian</a> Peninsulas, where they waded or dived for <a href="shellfish">shellfish</a>, as early as 150,000 years ago at <a href="Cueva%20Bajondillo">Cueva Bajondillo</a>, Spain, similar to the fishing record of modern humans. At <a href="Vanguard%20Cave">Vanguard Cave</a>, Gibraltar, the inhabitants consumed <a href="Mediterranean%20monk%20seal">Mediterranean monk seal</a>, <a href="short-beaked%20common%20dolphin">short-beaked common dolphin</a>, <a href="common%20bottlenose%20dolphin">common bottlenose dolphin</a>, <a href="Atlantic%20bluefin%20tuna">Atlantic bluefin tuna</a>, <a href="Diplodus">sea bream</a>, and <a href="Paracentrotus%20lividus">purple sea urchin</a>; and at <a href="Nature%20Park%20of%20Arr%C3%A1bida">Gruta da Figueira Brava</a>, Portugal, there is evidence of large-scale harvest of shellfish, <a href="crab">crab</a>s, and fish. Evidence of freshwater fishing was found in <a href="Castelcivita%20Cave">Grotte di Castelcivita</a>, Italy, for <a href="trout">trout</a>, <a href="chub">chub</a>, and <a href="eel">eel</a>; <a href="Abri%20du%20Maras">Abri du Maras</a>, France, for chub and <a href="European%20perch">European perch</a>; Payré, France; and <a href="Kudaro%20Cave">Kudaro Cave</a>, Russia, for <a href="Black%20Sea%20salmon">Black Sea salmon</a>.
Edible plant and mushroom remains are recorded from several caves. Neanderthals from Cueva del Sidrón, Spain, based on dental tartar, likely had a meatless diet of mushrooms, pine nuts, and moss, indicating they were forest foragers. Remnants from <a href="Amud%20Cave">Amud Cave</a>, Israel, indicates a diet of figs, palm tree fruits, and various <a href="cereal">cereal</a>s and edible grasses. Several bone traumas in the leg joints could possibly suggest habitual squatting, which, if the case, was likely done while gathering food. Dental <a href="Calculus%20%28dental%29">tartar</a> from <a href="Spy%20Cave">Grotte de Spy</a>, Belgium, indicates the inhabitants had a meat-heavy diet including woolly rhinoceros and <a href="mouflon">mouflon</a> sheep, while also regularly consuming mushrooms. Neanderthal faecal matter from <a href="El%20Salt">El Salt</a>, Spain, dated to 50,000 years ago—the oldest human faecal matter remains recorded—show a diet mainly of meat but with a significant component of plants. Evidence of cooked plant foods—mainly <a href="legume">legume</a>s and, to a far lesser extent, acorns—was discovered in <a href="Kebara%20Cave">Kebara Cave</a>, Israel, with its inhabitants possibly gathering plants in spring and fall and hunting in all seasons except fall, although the cave was probably abandoned in late summer to early fall. At Shanidar Cave, Iraq, Neanderthals collected plants with various harvest seasons, indicating they scheduled returns to the area to harvest certain plants, and that they had complex food-gathering behaviours for both meat and plants.
Food preparation.
Neanderthals probably could employ a wide range of cooking techniques, such as <a href="roasting">roasting</a>, and they may have been able to heat up or boil soup, stew, or animal <a href="Stock%20%28food%29">stock</a>. The abundance of animal bone fragments at settlements may indicate the making of fat stocks from boiling <a href="bone%20marrow">bone marrow</a>, possibly taken from animals that had already died of starvation. These methods would have substantially increased fat consumption, which was a major nutritional requirement of communities with low carbohydrate and high protein intake. Neanderthal tooth size had a decreasing trend after 100,000 years ago, which could indicate an increased dependence on cooking or the advent of boiling, a technique that would have softened food.
At Cueva del Sidrón, Spain, Neanderthals likely cooked and possibly <a href="smoking%20%28cooking%29">smoked</a> food, as well as used certain plants—such as <a href="yarrow">yarrow</a> and <a href="camomile">camomile</a>—as flavouring, although these plants may have instead been used for their medicinal properties. At <a href="Gorham%27s%20Cave">Gorham's Cave</a>, Gibraltar, Neanderthals may have been roasting <a href="pinecone">pinecone</a>s to access <a href="pine%20nut">pine nut</a>s.
At <a href="Grotte%20du%20Lazaret">Grotte du Lazaret</a>, France, a total of 23 red deer, 6 ibexes, 3 aurochs, and 1 <a href="roe%20deer">roe deer</a> appear to have been hunted in a single autumn hunting season, when strong male and female deer herds would group together for <a href="rut%20%28mammalian%20reproduction%29">rut</a>. The entire carcasses seem to have been transported to the cave and then butchered. Because this is such a large amount of food to consume before spoilage, it is possible these Neanderthals were <a href="curing%20%28food%20preservation%29">curing</a> and preserving it before winter set in. At 160,000 years old, it is the oldest potential evidence of food storage. The great quantities of meat and fat which could have been gathered in general from typical prey items (namely mammoths) could also indicate food storage capability. With shellfish, Neanderthals needed to eat, cook, or in some manner preserve them soon after collection, as shellfish spoils very quickly. At <a href="Cave%20of%20Los%20Aviones">Cueva de los Aviones</a>, Spain, the remains of edible, <a href="algae%20eater">algae eating</a> shellfish associated with the alga "<a href="Jania%20rubens">Jania rubens</a>" could indicate that, like some modern hunter gatherer societies, harvested shellfish were held in water-soaked algae to keep them alive and fresh until consumption.
Competition.
Competition from large <a href="Ice%20Age">Ice Age</a> predators was rather high. <a href="Panthera%20spelaea">Cave lion</a>s likely targeted horses, large deer and wild cattle; and <a href="Panthera%20pardus%20spelaea">leopards</a> primarily <a href="reindeer">reindeer</a> and roe deer; which heavily overlapped with Neanderthal diet. To defend a kill against such ferocious predators, Neanderthals may have engaged in a group display of yelling, arm waving, or stone throwing; or quickly gathered meat and abandoned the kill. However, at Grotte de Spy, Belgium, the remains of wolves, cave lions, and cave bears—which were all major predators of the time—indicate Neanderthals hunted their competitors to some extent.
Neanderthals and <a href="cave%20hyaena">cave hyaena</a>s may have exemplified <a href="niche%20differentiation">niche differentiation</a>, and actively avoided <a href="interspecific%20competition">competing</a> with each other. Although they both mainly targeted the same groups of creatures—deer, horses, and cattle—Neanderthals mainly hunted the former and cave hyaenas the latter two. Further, animal remains from Neanderthal caves indicate they preferred to hunt prime individuals, whereas cave hyaenas hunted weaker or younger prey, and cave hyaena caves have a higher abundance of carnivore remains. Nonetheless, there is evidence that cave hyaenas stole food and leftovers from Neanderthal campsites and scavenged on dead Neanderthal bodies.
Cannibalism.
There are several instances of Neanderthals practising <a href="human%20cannibalism">cannibalism</a> across their range. The first example came from <a href="Krapina%20Neanderthal%20site">Krapina</a>, Croatia, in 1899, and other examples were found at Cueva del Sidrón and <a href="Zafarraya">Zafarraya</a> in Spain; and the French <a href="Moula-Guercy%20Cave">Grotte de Moula-Guercy</a>, <a href="Les%20Pradelles">Les Pradelles</a>, and <a href="La%20Quina">La Quina</a>. For the five cannibalised Neanderthals at the <a href="Goyet%20Caves">Grottes de Goyet</a>, Belgium, there is evidence that the upper limbs were <a href="disarticulated">disarticulated</a>, the lower limbs <a href="excarnation">defleshed</a> and also smashed (likely to extract bone marrow), the chest cavity <a href="disemboweled">disemboweled</a>, and the jaw dismembered. There is also evidence that the butchers used some bones to <a href="retouch%20%28lithics%29">retouch</a> their tools. The processing of Neanderthal meat at Grottes de Goyet is similar to how they processed horse and reindeer. About 35% of the Neanderthals at <a href="Marillac-le-Franc">Marillac-le-Franc</a>, France, show clear signs of butchery, and the presence of digested teeth indicates that the bodies were abandoned and eaten by scavengers, likely hyaenas.
These cannibalistic tendencies have been explained as either <a href="ritual%20defleshing">ritual defleshing</a>, pre-burial defleshing (to prevent scavengers or foul smell), an act of war, or simply for food. Due to a small number of cases, and the higher number of cut marks seen on cannibalised individuals than animals (indicating inexperience), cannibalism was probably not a very common practice, and it may have only been done in times of extreme food shortages as in some <a href="List%20of%20incidents%20of%20cannibalism">cases in recorded human history</a>.
Art.
Personal adornment.
Neanderthal used ochre, a <a href="clay%20earth%20pigment">clay earth pigment</a>. Ochre is well-documented from 60 to 45 thousand years ago in Neanderthal sites, with the earliest example dating to 250–200 thousand years ago from <a href="Maastricht-Belv%C3%A9d%C3%A8re">Maastricht-Belvédère</a>, the Netherlands (a similar timespan to the ochre record of "H. sapiens"). It has been hypothesised to have functioned as body paint, and analyses of pigments from Pech de l’Azé, France, indicates they were applied to soft materials (such as a hide or human skin). However, modern hunter gatherers, in addition to body paint, also use ochre for medicine, for tanning hides, as a food preservative, and as an insect repellent, so its use as decorative paint for Neanderthals is speculative. Containers apparently used for mixing ochre pigments were found in <a href="Cioarei%20Cave">Peștera Cioarei</a>, Romania, which could indicate modification of ochre for solely aesthetic purposes.
Neanderthals collected uniquely shaped objects and are suggested to have modified them into pendants, such as a fossil "<a href="Aspa%20marginata">Aspa marginata</a>" sea snail shell possibly painted red from <a href="Grotta%20di%20Fumane">Grotta di Fumane</a>, Italy, transported over to the site about 47,500 years ago; 3 shells, dated to about 120–115 thousand years ago, perforated through the <a href="umbo%20%28bivalve%29">umbo</a> belonging to a <a href="Acanthocardia%20tuberculata">rough cockle</a>, a "<a href="Glycymeris%20insubrica">Glycymeris insubrica</a>", and a "<a href="Spondylus%20gaederopus">Spondylus gaederopus</a>" from Cueva de los Aviones, Spain, the former two associated with red and yellow pigments, and the latter a red-to-black mix of <a href="hematite">hematite</a> and <a href="pyrite">pyrite</a>; and a <a href="Pecten%20maximus">king scallop</a> shell with traces of an orange mix of <a href="goethite">goethite</a> and hematite from <a href="Cueva%20Ant%C3%B3n">Cueva Antón</a>, Spain. The discoverers of the latter two claim that pigment was applied to the exterior to make it match the naturally vibrant inside colouration. Excavated from 1949 to 1963 from the French <a href="Grotte%20du%20Renne">Grotte du Renne</a>, <a href="Ch%C3%A2telperronian">Châtelperronian</a> beads made from animal teeth, shells, and <a href="ivory">ivory</a> were found associated with Neanderthal bones, but the dating is uncertain and Châtelperronian artefacts may actually have been crafted by modern humans and simply redeposited with Neanderthal remains.
Gibraltarian palaeoanthropologists <a href="Clive%20Finlayson">Clive</a> and <a href="Geraldine%20Finlayson">Geraldine Finlayson</a> suggested that Neanderthals used various bird parts as artistic mediums, specifically black feathers. In 2012, the Finlaysons and colleagues examined 1,699 sites across Eurasia, and argued that <a href="Raptor%20%28bird%29">raptor</a>s and <a href="corvid">corvid</a>s, species not typically consumed by any human species, were overrepresented and show processing of only the wing bones instead of the fleshier torso, and thus are evidence of feather plucking of specifically the large <a href="flight%20feather">flight feather</a>s for use as personal adornment. They specifically noted the <a href="cinereous%20vulture">cinereous vulture</a>, <a href="red-billed%20chough">red-billed chough</a>, <a href="kestrel">kestrel</a>, <a href="lesser%20kestrel">lesser kestrel</a>, <a href="alpine%20chough">alpine chough</a>, <a href="rook%20%28bird%29">rook</a>, <a href="jackdaw">jackdaw</a>, and the <a href="white%20tailed%20eagle">white tailed eagle</a> in Middle Palaeolithic sites. Other birds claimed to present evidence of modifications by Neanderthals are the <a href="golden%20eagle">golden eagle</a>, <a href="rock%20pigeon">rock pigeon</a>, <a href="common%20raven">common raven</a>, and the <a href="bearded%20vulture">bearded vulture</a>. The earliest claim of bird bone jewellery is a number of 130,000 year old white tailed eagle talons found in a cache near Krapina, Croatia, speculated, in 2015, to have been a necklace. A similar 39,000-year-old <a href="Spanish%20imperial%20eagle">Spanish imperial eagle</a> talon necklace was reported in 2019 at <a href="Cova%20Forad%C3%A0">Cova Foradà</a> in Spain, though from the contentious Châtelperronian layer. In 2017, 17 incision-decorated raven bones from the <a href="Zaskalnaya%20VI">Zaskalnaya VI</a> rock shelter, Ukraine, dated to 43–38 thousand years ago were reported. Because the notches are more-or-less equidistant to each other, they are the first modified bird bones that cannot be explained by simple butchery, and for which the argument of design intent is based on direct evidence.
Discovered in 1975, the so-called <a href="Mask%20of%20la%20Roche-Cotard">Mask of la Roche-Cotard</a>, a mostly flat piece of flint with a bone pushed through a hole on the midsection—dated to 32, 40, or 75 thousand years ago—has been purported to resemble the upper half of a face, with the bone representing eyes. It is contested whether it represents a face, or if it even counts as art. In 1988, American archaeologist <a href="Alexander%20Marshack">Alexander Marshack</a> speculated that a Neanderthal at <a href="Grotte%20de%20L%27Hortus">Grotte de L'Hortus</a>, France, wore a leopard pelt as personal adornment to indicate elevated status in the group based on a recovered leopard skull, <a href="phalange">phalange</a>s, and <a href="tail%20vertebra">tail vertebra</a>e.
Abstraction.
As of 2014, 63 purported engravings have been reported from 27 different European and Middle Eastern Lower-to-Middle Palaeolithic sites, of which 20 are on flint cortexes from 11 sites, 7 are on slabs from 7 sites, and 36 are on pebbles from 13 sites. It is debated whether or not these were made with symbolic intent. In 2012, <a href="Gorham%27s%20Cave%23Scratched%20floor">deep scratches</a> on the floor of Gorham's Cave, Gibraltar, were discovered, dated to older than 39,000 years ago, which the discoverers have interpreted as Neanderthal <a href="abstract%20art">abstract art</a>. The scratches could have also been produced by a bear. In 2021, an Irish elk phalanx with five engraved offset <a href="Chevron%20%28insignia%29">chevrons</a> stacked above each other was discovered at the entrance to the <a href="Einhornh%C3%B6hle">Einhornhöhle cave</a> in Germany, dating to about 51,000 years ago.
In 2018, some red-painted dots, disks, lines, and hand stencils on the cave walls of the Spanish <a href="La%20Pasiega">La Pasiega</a>, <a href="Maltravieso">Maltravieso</a>, and <a href="Do%C3%B1a%20Trinidad">Doña Trinidad</a> were dated to be older than 66,000 years ago, at least 20,000 years prior to the arrival of modern humans in Western Europe. This would indicate Neanderthal authorship, and similar iconography recorded in other Western European sites—such as <a href="Vall%C3%A9e%20des%20merveilles">Les Merveilles</a>, France, and <a href="Cave%20of%20El%20Castillo">Cueva del Castillo</a>, Spain—could potentially also have Neanderthal origins. However, the dating of these Spanish caves, and thus attribution to Neanderthals, is contested.
Neanderthals are known to have collected a variety of unusual objects—such as crystals or fossils—without any real functional purpose or any indication of damage caused by use. It is unclear if these objects were simply picked up for their aesthetic qualities, or if some symbolic significance was applied to them. These items are mainly <a href="quartz%20crystal">quartz crystal</a>s, but also other minerals such as <a href="cerussite">cerussite</a>, <a href="iron%20pyrite">iron pyrite</a>, <a href="calcite">calcite</a>, and <a href="galena">galena</a>. A few findings feature modifications, such as a mammoth tooth with an incision and a fossil <a href="nummulite">nummulite</a> shell with a cross etched in from <a href="Tata%2C%20Hungary">Tata, Hungary</a>; a large slab with 18 <a href="cupstone">cupstone</a>s hollowed out from a grave in La Ferrassie, France; and a <a href="geode">geode</a> from Peștera Cioarei, Romania, coated with red ochre. A number of fossil shells are also known from French Neanderthals sites, such as a <a href="rhynchonellid">rhynchonellid</a> and a "<a href="Taraebratulina">Taraebratulina</a>" from <a href="Combe%20Grenal">Combe Grenal</a>; a <a href="belemnite">belemnite</a> beak from <a href="Grottes%20des%20Canalettes">Grottes des Canalettes</a>; a <a href="polyp%20%28zoology%29">polyp</a> from <a href="Grotte%20de%20l%27Hy%C3%A8ne">Grotte de l'Hyène</a>; a sea urchin from <a href="La%20Gonterie-Boulouneix">La Gonterie-Boulouneix</a>; and a <a href="rhynchonella">rhynchonella</a>, <a href="feather%20star">feather star</a>, and belemnite beak from the contentious Châtelperronian layer of Grotte du Renne.
Music.
Purported Neanderthal <a href="bone%20flute">bone flute</a> fragments made of bear long bones were reported from <a href="Potok%20Cave">Potočka zijalka</a>, Slovenia, in the 1920s, and <a href="Ist%C3%A1ll%C3%B3s-k%C5%91">Istállós-kői-barlang</a>, Hungary, and <a href="Mokri%C5%A1ka%20jama">Mokriška jama</a>, Slovenia, in 1985; but these are now attributed to modern human activities. The 1995 43 thousand year old <a href="Divje%20Babe%20Flute">Divje Babe Flute</a> from Slovenia has been attributed by some researchers to Neanderthals, and Canadian musicologist Robert Fink said the original flute had either a <a href="diatonic%20scale">diatonic</a> or <a href="pentatonic%20scale">pentatonic</a> musical scale. However, the date also overlaps with modern human immigration into Europe, which means it is also possible it was not manufactured by Neanderthals. In 2015, zoologist Cajus Diedrich argued that it was not a flute at all, and the holes were made by a scavenging hyaena as there is a lack of cut marks stemming from whittling, but in 2018, Slovenian archaeologist Matija Turk and colleagues countered that it is highly unlikely the punctures were made by teeth, and cut marks are not always present on bone flutes.
Technology.
